articles.headline: New Hampshire Voters Hear Candidates’ Final Appeals Before Primary
articles.snippet: As the snow fell, the Republican and Democratic candidates carried on, with at least one front-runner wondering how the weather would affect turnout.
articles.abstract: As the snow fell, the Republican and Democratic candidates carried on, with at least one front-runner wondering how the weather would affect turnout.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — A rambunctious herd of presidential candidates dashed across a snowy New Hampshire on Monday, making last-ditch efforts to persuade undecided voters on the eve of the nation’s first primary election, the outcome of which could bring a dose of clarity to a campaign that has become surprisingly muddled.

articles.headline: New, Reading-Heavy SAT Has Students Worried
articles.snippet: Some educators fear that the revised test — one of the biggest redesigns ever — will penalize certain students, like immigrants and the poor.
articles.abstract: Some educators fear that the revised test — one of the biggest redesigns ever — will penalize certain students, like immigrants and the poor.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — For thousands of college hopefuls, the stressful college admissions season is about to become even more fraught. The College Board, which makes the SAT, is rolling out a new test — its biggest redesign in a decade, and one of the most substantial ever.

articles.headline: Undeclared in New Hampshire: ‘I Might Be Able to Bring Trump and Cruz Down’
articles.snippet: Undeclared voters are grappling with a wildly diverse field, and a new poll says 23 percent are still open to changing their minds.
articles.abstract: Undeclared voters are grappling with a wildly diverse field, and a new poll says 23 percent are still open to changing their minds.
articles.lead_paragraph: RINDGE, N.H. — After hours of deliberation and debate, Joleen Little had narrowed down her choice for president in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday to two candidates — a liberal Democrat and a conservative Republican.

articles.headline: Russian Companies Rush to Return to Post-Sanctions Iran
articles.snippet: Russia has an advantage in pursuing trade with Iran because it has long backed the country diplomatically and it has strong military ties.
articles.abstract: Russia has an advantage in pursuing trade with Iran because it has long backed the country diplomatically and it has strong military ties.
articles.lead_paragraph: VOLGOGRAD, Russia — At a sprawling pipe factory in this gritty industrial town, an exhibit of Surrealist art, featuring reproductions of Mondrian, Malevich and Magritte, lines the walls. One of the company’s biggest shareholders, a collector of Surrealist works, says the art will stretch engineers’ minds and unlock workers’ creativity.

articles.headline: Roadblocks on the Route From Wall Street to Washington
articles.snippet: No matter who wins the presidency this fall, chances are slim that anyone connected to Wall Street has a prayer of securing a top post in the administration.
articles.abstract: No matter who wins the presidency this fall, chances are slim that anyone connected to Wall Street has a prayer of securing a top post in the administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: For some at the top of Wall Street, there is only one job considered better: a top job in Washington.

articles.headline: U.N. Agency Proposes Limits on Airlines’ Carbon Emissions
articles.snippet: The proposed new rules by the International Civil Aviation Organization, the United Nations’ aviation agency, would apply for all new airplanes delivered after 2028.
articles.abstract: The proposed new rules by the International Civil Aviation Organization, the United Nations’ aviation agency, would apply for all new airplanes delivered after 2028.
articles.lead_paragraph: After more than six years of negotiations, the global aviation industry agreed on Monday to the first binding limits on carbon dioxide emissions, tackling the fastest-growing source of greenhouse gas pollution.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Coral Davenport

articles.headline: Traveling Through Venezuela, a Country Teetering on the Brink
articles.snippet: Our reporter explores the country and its people in his first 30 days in the region on assignment for The Times.
articles.abstract: Our reporter explores the country and its people in his first 30 days in the region on assignment for The Times.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUERTO CABELLO, Venezuela — In the capital, water is so expensive and scarce that residents wait for hours with bottles at the side of a mountain where it trickles out onto the highway.

articles.headline: Japan Bond Yield Slides Below Zero and Stocks Fall
articles.snippet: Investors react to a recent surprise rate decision by the central bank, and stocks fall sharply as the yen gathers strength.
articles.abstract: Investors react to a recent surprise rate decision by the central bank, and stocks fall sharply as the yen gathers strength.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Given Japan’s outsize public debt, holding an i.o.u. from its government might seem like a risky proposition that would require the promise of a substantial reward.
